content: I am a tenant in San Francisco living in a rent-controlled apartment. My landlord is trying to increase my rent by 20% which seems excessive.

I am not your lawyer and this is not legal advice. If you need tailored guidance, consult a licensed California attorney.

It sounds incredibly stressful to face such a significant rent increase. In San Francisco, rent-controlled units are generally subject to the regulations set by the San Francisco Rent Ordinance, which typically limits annual rent increases to a percentage based on the Consumer Price Index. As of the most recent updates, this increase is usually around 1-2% per year, far less than the 20% your landlord is proposing.

Could you please confirm the zip code of your rental unit so I can provide more precise information? Additionally, knowing when you received the notice of the rent increase would be helpful.
I live in a building built in 1965 and have been there for 5 years. The maintenance issues with plumbing have been ongoing for months. My zip code is 94117.

It sounds like you're dealing with multiple significant issues in your apartment. Given that your building is rent-controlled and was built in 1965, any rent increase should adhere to the guidelines set by the San Francisco Rent Ordinance. Increases over the allowable percentage, which is typically tied to the Consumer Price Index and generally around 1-2% annually, need to be justified by allowable pass-throughs or other legal exceptions.

Regarding the ongoing plumbing issues, landlords are required under California Civil Code ยง1941.1 to maintain rental properties in a habitable condition, which includes working plumbing. If these issues have been persistent and unaddressed despite your notifications to the landlord, this could be a violation of your rights as a tenant.

To better assist you, could you tell me when exactly you received the notice of the rent increase? This will help determine if the notice was given in accordance with legal requirements.
I received the rent increase notice last week. I pay $2500 per month currently. The landlord says he needs to increase rent to cover renovation costs in other units. My lease expires in 2 months.

It sounds quite challenging to deal with a sudden rent increase, especially when it's to cover costs that don't directly benefit your unit. In San Francisco, the Rent Ordinance typically restricts rent increases in rent-controlled units to an annual allowable percentage, which is usually around 1-2%. Increases above this rate, particularly for reasons like funding renovations in other units, are generally not permissible unless they fall under specific allowable pass-throughs, which usually do not include renovations of other units.

Since your lease is expiring soon, it's also important to consider whether your landlord intends to offer you a new lease or move to a month-to-month agreement, which could affect your rights and options.
